title: fmail TUI: Live Tail mode
body:
Build the Live Tail mode  a focused, real-time message stream with filtering.

## Layout
```
 LIVE TAIL  filter: from:architect priority:high 
                                                           
  15:30:01 [task] architect  task                        
    implement JWT auth for the user service.               
    Requirements: RS256 signing, 15min expiry...           
                                                           
  15:31:15 [task] coder-1  task                          
    on it, ETA 30min. Quick question  should              
    refresh tokens be single-use or reusable?              
                                                           
  15:32:00 [build] architect  build                      
    run full test suite                                    
                                                           
  15:33:22 [DM] coder-1  @architect                     
    need clarification on token refresh flow               
                                                           
    (auto-scrolling  Space to pause)                    
                                                           
 12 msg/m 
 Space: pause/resume  f: filter  /: search  c: clear  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Real-time message stream:
  - Subscribe to ALL messages via the data provider's Subscribe()
  - Messages displayed full-width with topic tag prefix: [topic] or [DM]
  - Agent names in their assigned colors
  - Timestamps at second precision (HH:MM:SS)
  - Message body shown in full (up to 5 lines, truncate with "..." beyond)
  - Horizontal rule (thin line) between messages from different topics
- Auto-scroll behavior:
  - Default: auto-scroll to newest message as they arrive
  - Space bar: pause auto-scroll (show "PAUSED" indicator + buffered message count)
  - While paused: new messages still buffered, scroll indicator shows count
  - Space again or End/G: resume auto-scroll, flush buffer to view
  - Scroll up with j/k///PgUp to manually browse while paused
- Filtering (press `f` to open filter bar):
  - Filter syntax: `from:<agent> to:<topic> priority:<high|normal|low> tag:<tag> text:<pattern>`
  - Multiple filters ANDed together
  - Filter applied in real-time  non-matching messages hidden
  - Show active filter in the header
  - Clear filter with `c` or edit with `f`
  - Quick filters: `1` = high priority only, `2` = DMs only, `3` = current agent's messages
- Keyword highlighting:
  - Press `h` to set highlight patterns (regex)
  - Matching text rendered in bold/underline with accent color
  - Multiple highlight patterns supported (each gets a different color)
  - Highlights persist across the session (stored in TUI state)
- Message rate indicator:
  - Footer shows messages per minute (rolling 60s window)
  - Sparkline of message rate over last 10 minutes
- Flash notification:
  - On high-priority messages: briefly flash the header bar (invert colors for 500ms)
  - Terminal bell on high-priority if sound alerts enabled in preferences

## Technical Notes
- This is essentially a filtered view of the Subscribe() channel
- Buffer size: 2000 messages max (drop oldest), configurable
- When paused, keep buffering but don't render  flush on resume
- Filter parsing: simple key:value parser, no need for a full query language
- Highlight patterns compiled to regexp on set, applied during render
- Message rate: ring buffer of timestamps, count entries in last 60s
- Performance: this view can see high throughput  batch renders (max 1 render per 50ms)

title: fmail TUI: Search and Filter engine
body:
Build comprehensive search and filter functionality accessible from any view.

## Layout
```
 Search 
 > from:architect tag:auth since:1h token refresh_        
                                                          
  Saved: [auth-discussion] [high-priority] [today]        
                                                          
  12 results (searched 342 messages in 8 topics)          
                                                          
   [task] architect (15:30)  2 matches                 
    implement JWT auth...token refresh with sliding window 
    matching context 
                                                          
    [task] coder-1 (15:31)  1 match                     
    ...should refresh tokens be single-use or reusable?   
                                                          
    [@coder-1] architect (15:34)  1 match               
    Single-use. Each refresh mints a new refresh token... 
                                                          
    [build] architect (15:32)  0 matches (context)      
    run full test suite (adjacent to matching thread)      
                                                          

 Enter: open thread  Tab: next match  s: save search  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Search input bar:
  - Full-width text input at the top of the view
  - Real-time search-as-you-type with debounce (200ms after last keystroke)
  - Query syntax (all optional, combinable):
    - Free text: matches against message body (case-insensitive)
    - `from:<agent>`  filter by sender (supports glob: `from:coder-*`)
    - `to:<topic|@agent>`  filter by target
    - `priority:<high|normal|low>`  filter by priority
    - `tag:<tag>`  filter by tag (multiple tag: filters ANDed)
    - `since:<duration>`  messages newer than (1h, 30m, 2d, 1w)
    - `until:<duration>`  messages older than
    - `has:reply`  only messages that have been replied to
    - `has:bookmark`  only bookmarked messages
    - `is:unread`  only unread messages
    - `in:<topic>`  scope to specific topic
  - Syntax highlighting in the input: keywords in blue, values in green, free text in white
  - Tab completion for agent names, topic names, and filter keywords
- Search results:
  - Grouped by topic, sorted by relevance (match count) then recency
  - Each result shows: topic tag, agent (colored), timestamp, match count
  - Matching text highlighted with bold/underline in the message body
  - Context: show 1 message before and after each match for context
  - Result count and search performance stats in header ("12 results in 342 messages")
- Result navigation:
  - j/k to move between results
  - Tab/Shift+Tab to jump between highlighted matches
  - Enter on a result  push to Thread View, scrolled to that message
  - `o` to open the message in context (show surrounding thread)
- Saved searches:
  - Press `s` to save current search with a name
  - Saved searches shown as pills below the search bar
  - Click/Enter on a pill to load that search
  - `x` on a pill to delete it
  - Saved in tui-state.json
- Search index (optimization for large message stores):
  - Build an in-memory inverted index on first search
  - Index: word  set of message IDs
  - Rebuild index on new messages (incremental: only index new messages)
  - Falls back to linear scan if index not ready

## Technical Notes
- Search runs against the data provider's Search() method
- For the inverted index: tokenize message bodies by splitting on whitespace/punctuation
- Case-insensitive matching: lowercase all tokens in the index
- Glob matching for from:/to: filters: use filepath.Match semantics
- Duration parsing: support h (hours), m (minutes), d (days), w (weeks)
- Performance: search should feel instant for <1000 messages, <500ms for 10,000+
- Debounce search-as-you-type to avoid excessive re-renders

title: fmail TUI: Timeline / Sequence Diagram view
body:
Build a Timeline view that shows messages chronologically across all topics, with an optional sequence-diagram swim-lane mode.

## Layout  Chronological Mode
```
 Timeline  15:00 - 15:45 
                                                          
  15:30:01  architect  task  
              implement JWT auth for the user service     
                                                          
  15:31:15  coder-1  task  
              on it, ETA 30min                            
                                                          
  15:32:00  architect  build  
              run full test suite                         
                                                          
  15:33:22  coder-1  @architect (DM)  
              need clarification on token refresh         
                                                          
  15:34:10  architect  @coder-1 (DM)  
              Single-use. Each refresh mints a new...     
                                                          
               5 minutes shown (zoom: +/- to adjust)   

 +/- zoom  / pan  f filter  s swim-lane  Esc back
```

## Layout  Swim-Lane (Sequence Diagram) Mode
```
 Sequence  15:00 - 15:45 
    architect     coder-1      tester      reviewer       
                                                       
  15:30 task                                   
                                                       
  15:31 task                                   
                                                       
  15:32 build                       
                                                       
  15:33 DM                                   
                                                       
  15:34 DM                                   
                                                       
                                                       

 +/- zoom  / pan  t timeline  Enter: detail  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Chronological timeline mode:
  - ALL messages across all topics interleaved in strict time order
  - Each message: timestamp (HH:MM:SS), agent (colored)  target, first line of body
  - Vertical time axis on the left
  - Visual time gaps: if >5 minutes between messages, show a gap indicator (" 15 min gap ")
  - Reply connectors: if a message is a reply, show a thin connecting line to the parent
  - Topic-colored left border on each message (each topic gets a color in addition to agents)
  - Zoom levels: 1 min, 5 min, 15 min, 1h, 4h, 1d (changes visible time window)
  - Pan: / arrows or h/l to move the time window
  - Jump to now: press `n` to snap to current time
  - Jump to time: press `t` and type a time/date to jump there
- Swim-lane (sequence diagram) mode:
  - Toggle with `s` key
  - Each active agent gets a vertical column (lane)
  - Messages shown as horizontal arrows from sender to receiver
  - Arrow labels: topic name (abbreviated)
  - DMs shown as dashed arrows
  - Broadcast messages (topic posts) shown as arrows to all participants in that topic
  - Time axis on the left (same zoom/pan as timeline mode)
  - Agents sorted by first appearance (or alphabetically, toggle with `a`)
  - Auto-hide inactive agents (agents with no messages in visible window)
  - Max 8 lanes visible (scroll horizontally for more)
  - Arrow colors: match the topic color
- Filtering:
  - Same filter syntax as Search view
  - Press `f` to set filter, narrows visible messages
  - Quick filters: by topic, by agent, by priority
- Message detail:
  - Enter on a message  popup overlay with full message details
  - From the popup: `r` to reply, `b` to bookmark, `o` to open in Thread View

## Technical Notes
- This requires loading all messages in the visible time range across all topics
- Pre-sort all messages by timestamp (they already have sortable IDs)
- Swim-lane rendering: compute column positions based on terminal width and agent count
  - Each lane: agent name header + vertical line ()
  - Arrows:  or  with label
  - Use Unicode box-drawing characters for clean rendering
- Zoom: each level defines a time.Duration window, pan moves by 25% of window
- For large time ranges, only load message metadata (ID, from, to, time) and lazy-load bodies
- This is the most rendering-intensive view  optimize with viewport virtualization
- Cache time-sorted message lists per topic, merge with a k-way merge for cross-topic timeline

title: fmail TUI: Replay Mode (time-travel playback)
body:
Build a Replay Mode that allows scrubbing through historical message activity at variable speed.

## Layout
```
 REPLAY   10x  15:30:00 / 16:45:00 
                                                          
  (same layout as Live Dashboard or Timeline, but         
   showing historical state at the playback cursor)       
                                                          
  Agents at 15:30:                                        
   architect (active)                                    
   coder-1 (idle since 15:15)                           
                                                          
  Messages arriving:                                      
  15:30:01 architect  task                              
    implement JWT auth...                                 
  ... (messages appear as time advances) ...              
                                                          

       PLAYING                                  
  [=========>-----------] 15:30  16:45        
  Speed: [1x] [5x] [10x] [50x]                          

 Space: play/pause  /: skip  1-4: speed  Home/End: start/end
```

## Deliverables
- Playback scrubber:
  - Horizontal progress bar showing position within the replay time range
  - Time range: auto-detected from first to last message in the store (or user-specified)
  - Current playback position shown as HH:MM:SS above the scrubber
  - Drag/click on scrubber to jump to any point (or use / to step)
  - /: skip forward/back by 1 message
  - Shift+/: skip forward/back by 1 minute
  - Home/End: jump to start/end
- Playback controls:
  - Space: play/pause
  - Speed presets: 1 = real-time (1x), 2 = 5x, 3 = 10x, 4 = 50x
  - Speed shown in the header
  - During playback, messages appear in the feed at accelerated rate
  - Each message "arrives" at its relative timestamp scaled by speed
- Replay view:
  - Default: uses the Live Dashboard layout (agents + feed)
  - Toggle to Timeline layout with `t`
  - Agent presence recalculated at each point in time:
    - An agent is "active" if they sent a message within the last 5 minutes (relative to playback position)
  - Message feed shows only messages up to the current playback position
  - New messages "arrive" with a brief highlight animation (bold for 500ms)
- Replay state:
  - "State at time T" computation:
    - Active agents: filter agent records by activity relative to T
    - Active topics: topics with messages before T
    - Unread counts: as if ReadMarkers were at T
    - Message feed: all messages with timestamp  T
  - Pre-compute a sorted list of all message timestamps for efficient seeking
- Bookmarkable positions:
  - Press `m` to mark the current position (like vim marks)
  - Press `'` + letter to jump to a marked position
  - Marks shown as notches on the scrubber bar
- Export:
  - Press `e` to export the visible time range as a markdown report
  - Report includes: time range, active agents, all messages formatted
  - Written to .fmail/exports/replay-YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS.md

## Technical Notes
- Pre-load all messages sorted by timestamp into memory for the replay session
- Use a timer (tea.Tick) for playback, interval = (real_time_between_messages / speed)
- For gaps >30s between messages at current speed, fast-forward the clock (don't make users wait)
- Replay mode is read-only  no sending messages from this view
- State computation should be efficient: use binary search on sorted timestamps for "messages up to T"
- Memory: for very large message stores (>100K messages), stream from disk instead of pre-loading
- Playback position persisted in TUI state so user can resume replay later

title: fmail TUI: Conversation Graph (agent interaction network)
body:
Build a Conversation Graph view showing agent-to-agent communication as a network visualization.

## Layout
```
 Graph  last 4h  156 messages 
                                                          
                                              
              > coder-1  <                     
                    (42)                              
                                            
                15 msgs           8 msgs               
                                 
         architect         reviewer                  
           (67)          (23)                   
           23                     
                                                         
         7 msgs                                          
                                               
          tester                                        
           (12)                                         
                                               
                                                          
  Legend: (N) = total messages sent                       
  Edge = message count between agents                    
   = high volume   = low volume                    

 +/- zoom  // pan  Enter: detail  period: [/]  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Network graph rendering:
  - Each agent is a node (box) with: name (colored) + total message count
  - Edges between agents who have communicated (DMs or shared topics)
  - Edge thickness proportional to message volume:
    - Thin () for 1-5 messages
    - Medium () for 6-20 messages
    - Thick (double ) for 20+ messages
  - Edge labels: message count
  - Directed edges: arrows showing which direction messages flow ()
  - Bidirectional edges: double arrows ()
  - Node size (box width) proportional to total messages sent
  - Layout algorithm: force-directed (simplified for terminal):
    - Most-connected agent in center
    - Agents positioned by connectivity (closer = more messages between them)
    - Avoid overlapping boxes
- Time range:
  - Default: last 4 hours
  - Adjustable with `[` (shrink) and `]` (expand): 1h, 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, all-time
  - Graph re-renders with updated data for the selected range
  - Show time range and total message count in header
- Interaction:
  - Navigate between nodes with ///
  - Enter on a node  show popup with agent detail (messages sent/received, top topics, top correspondents)
  - Enter on an edge  show messages between those two agents
  - `c`  toggle cluster detection: auto-group agents that form working clusters
    - Clusters drawn as dotted rectangles around agent groups
    - Cluster = agents with >50% of their messages going to other cluster members
- Topic overlay:
  - Press `t` to toggle topic overlay
  - Topics shown as circles instead of boxes
  - Edges go agent  topic  agent, showing which topics connect agents
  - Color-coded by topic

## Technical Notes
- Terminal graph rendering is inherently limited  keep it simple and readable
- Force-directed layout: simplified version
  1. Start with agents in a circle
  2. Iteratively: attract connected nodes, repel all nodes, settle after N iterations
  3. Snap to character grid (each node occupies a rectangular area)
  4. Max 12 agents displayed (combine least-active into an "others" node)
- For rendering: use box-drawing characters () and arrows ()
- Edge routing: simple Manhattan routing (horizontal then vertical) with collision avoidance
- This view is optional/secondary  prioritize it being informative over perfectly laid out
- Re-render only when time range changes or on explicit refresh, not on every message

title: fmail TUI: Activity Heatmap view
body:
Build an Activity Heatmap showing agent communication patterns over time, similar to GitHub's contribution graph.

## Layout
```
 Activity Heatmap  last 24h 
                                                          
  Hour:  00  02  04  06  08  10  12  14  16  18  20  22  
           
 archit                   
 coder-1                  
 tester                   
 review                         
 deploy                            
           
                                                          
  Legend:  1-5 msgs   6-15 msgs   16+ msgs           
                                                          

  Summary:                                                
  Peak hour: 14:00-15:00 (47 messages)                   
  Most active: architect (67 msgs)                       
  Busiest topic: task (89 msgs)                          
  Avg response time: 2m 15s                              

 [/] time range  s: sort  t: topic view  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Heatmap grid:
  - Rows: one per agent (sorted by total activity, most active at top)
  - Columns: time buckets (granularity depends on range)
    - 24h view: 1-hour buckets (24 columns)
    - 7d view: 4-hour buckets (42 columns)
    - 30d view: 1-day buckets (30 columns)
  - Cell intensity: block characters with varying density
    - Empty: no messages
    -  (light): 1-5 messages
    -  (medium): 6-15 messages
    -  (dense): 16-30 messages
    -  (full): 31+ messages
  - Color scale: cool (blue/cyan) for low activity  warm (yellow/red) for high
  - Thresholds auto-scaled to the data (percentile-based)
- Time range controls:
  - `[` to shrink, `]` to expand: 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, 30d
  - / to pan the time window
  - Current range shown in header
- Topic heatmap mode:
  - Press `t` to toggle: rows become topics instead of agents
  - Shows which topics are hot at which times
  - Same color scale and controls
- Summary panel (below heatmap):
  - Peak hour: time bucket with most messages
  - Most active agent: agent with highest message count in range
  - Busiest topic: topic with highest message count in range
  - Average response time: mean time between a message and its first reply (across all threads)
  - Total messages in range
  - Unique agents active in range
- Sort options:
  - `s` cycles: by total activity, by name, by peak time, by recency
- Cell detail:
  - Navigate to a cell with arrow keys
  - Show tooltip: "architect, 14:00-15:00: 23 messages (task: 15, build: 5, DMs: 3)"
  - Enter on a cell  filter Timeline view to that agent + time range

## Technical Notes
- Heatmap data: aggregate message counts into time buckets per agent
- Pre-compute when entering the view (scan all messages in time range)
- Auto-scale thresholds: compute percentiles (25th, 50th, 75th, 95th) of non-zero cell values
- Response time calculation: for each message with reply_to, compute delta between reply and parent
  - Cache this per-thread, only recompute for new messages
- Rendering: each cell is 3 characters wide (to fit in standard terminals)
- For 30d view with many agents, support vertical scrolling
- Agent name column: truncate to 8 chars with "..." for narrow terminals

title: fmail TUI: Stats Dashboard view
body:
Build a Stats Dashboard showing aggregate communication metrics and analytics.

## Layout
```
 Stats  last 24h 
                                                          
  OVERVIEW                      MESSAGES OVER TIME       
  Total messages: 342              
  Active agents:  6                
  Active topics:  8             06:00     12:00    18:00 
  Avg reply time: 2m 15s                                
  Longest thread: 12 msgs      TOPIC VOLUME             
                                task      89     
  TOP AGENTS (by msgs sent)     build     52        
  1. architect   67    review    43         
  2. coder-1     52      editing   23           
  3. reviewer    43       deploy    12            
  4. tester      23                                  
  5. deployer    12           RESPONSE LATENCY         
                                <30s    45%  
  BUSIEST HOUR                  1-5m   28%        
  14:00-15:00 (47 msgs)        5-30m  18%          
                                >30m   9%             

 [/] time range  r: refresh  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Overview panel:
  - Total message count in time range
  - Unique active agents (agents who sent at least 1 message)
  - Unique active topics
  - Average reply time (mean of reply-to-parent deltas)
  - Median reply time
  - Longest thread (most messages in a single reply chain)
  - Most replied-to message (message with the most direct replies)
- Top agents:
  - Sorted list of agents by messages sent
  - Horizontal bar chart using block characters
  - Show: rank, agent name (colored), count, bar
  - Top 10, or all if fewer
- Messages over time:
  - Line chart / sparkline showing message volume over time
  - X-axis: time, Y-axis: message count per bucket
  - Bucket size depends on time range (same as heatmap)
  - Use braille characters () for high-resolution sparkline
  - Or use block characters () for simpler rendering
- Topic volume:
  - Horizontal bar chart of messages per topic
  - Sorted by volume descending
  - Color-coded bars (topic colors)
- Response latency distribution:
  - Histogram of reply times bucketed into: <30s, 30s-5m, 5m-30m, 30m-2h, >2h
  - Horizontal bar chart with percentage
  - Color-coded: green (<30s), yellow (30s-5m), orange (5m-30m), red (>30m)
- Busiest hour:
  - Single highlighted stat: the hour with most messages
  - "Quietest hour" below it
- Time range controls:
  - Same as heatmap: [/] to adjust, / to pan
  - 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, 30d, all-time
- Auto-refresh: recompute every 30 seconds when live data is flowing
- Thread depth analysis:
  - Average thread depth (number of messages per thread)
  - Distribution: 1 msg (standalone), 2-3, 4-10, 10+
  - Shown as small bar chart or counts

## Technical Notes
- All stats computed from in-memory message data (same cache as other views)
- Response latency: only count messages where reply_to exists and parent is found
- Sparkline rendering: use a ring buffer of bucket counts, render proportional heights
- Braille sparklines: charmbracelet/bubbles has a sparkline component, or implement with braille unicode block (U+2800-U+28FF)
- For "all-time" range, scan entire .fmail/ store  may be slow, show loading indicator
- Cache computed stats, invalidate on new messages

title: fmail TUI: Compose and Send messages
body:
Build inline message composition and sending directly from the TUI.

## Layout  Compose Overlay
```
 Compose 
                                                          
  To: task_______        (Tab to autocomplete)            
  Priority: [normal ]                                    
  Tags: auth, urgent_    (comma-separated)                
  Reply to: 20260209-153000-0001  (auto-filled)          
                                                          
   
   Here's the implementation plan for JWT auth:         
                                                        
   1. RS256 signing with rotating keys                  
   2. 15-minute access token expiry                     
   3. Single-use refresh tokens                         
                                                        
   I'll start with the token service.                   
   
                                                          
  [Ctrl+Enter: Send]  [Esc: Cancel]  [Tab: Next field]   

```

## Deliverables
- Compose overlay (modal):
  - Triggered by: `n` (new message), `r` (reply to selected message)
  - Semi-transparent overlay on top of current view
  - Fields:
    - To: text input with tab-completion for agent names (@agent) and topic names
      - Autocomplete dropdown showing matching agents/topics as user types
      - Pre-filled when replying (to = sender of selected message) or when in a topic view
    - Priority: dropdown selector (low / normal / high), default normal
    - Tags: comma-separated text input with tab-completion for existing tags
    - Reply to: auto-filled when using `r`, shows the parent message ID + preview
    - Body: multi-line text area (main input)
  - Tab cycles between fields, Enter in single-line fields moves to next field
  - Ctrl+Enter: send the message
  - Esc: cancel (with confirmation if body is non-empty: "Discard draft?")
- Message sending:
  - Sends via the data provider (which uses forged socket if available, file store otherwise)
  - Show sending indicator ("Sending...") with spinner
  - On success: close overlay, show brief "Sent " notification, message appears in feed
  - On error: show error message in the overlay, keep draft intact for retry
  - Set FMAIL_AGENT identity from CLI flag or auto-detect
- Reply mode:
  - `r` on a selected message  opens compose with:
    - To: pre-filled with the topic (or @sender for DMs)
    - Reply to: set to the selected message's ID
    - Body: empty, but header shows "Replying to: <first line of parent message>"
  - `R` (shift+r)  reply to sender directly (DM) regardless of where the original was posted
- Quick send:
  - From any view, press `:` to open a one-line quick send bar at the bottom
  - Syntax: `:<target> <message>` (e.g., `:task implement JWT auth`)
  - Press Enter to send immediately
  - No priority/tag/reply-to options (uses defaults)
  - Great for fast, informal messages
- Draft persistence:
  - If user navigates away from compose (Esc), offer to save draft
  - Drafts stored in tui-state.json
  - On next compose, offer to restore last draft if target matches

## Technical Notes
- Multi-line text input: use charmbracelet/bubbles textarea component
- Tab completion: build a trie or sorted list of known agents/topics, filter on prefix
- Autocomplete dropdown: rendered as a small list below the input, navigate with /
- Send via fmail store: write JSON message file to .fmail/topics/<topic>/ or .fmail/dm/<agent>/
  - Or send via forged socket: {"cmd":"send","to":"<target>","body":"<msg>","agent":"<self>"}
- Identity: the TUI needs to know "who am I"  set via --agent flag or FMAIL_AGENT env var
  - If not set, register as "tui-<pid>" or prompt user on first send
- Ctrl+Enter detection: tea.KeyMsg with ctrl+enter (may need platform-specific handling)

title: fmail TUI: Bookmarks and Annotations
body:
Build bookmarking and annotation features for saving and annotating important messages.

## Layout  Bookmarks Panel
```
 Bookmarks  12 saved 
                                                          
 Filter: _________                                        
                                                          
  "JWT auth decision"  architect in task (15:34)       
   Note: Final decision was single-use refresh tokens     
                                                          
   "Test command"  tester in build (14:20)              
   Note: go test ./auth/... -tags=integration             
                                                          
   "Deploy checklist"  deployer in deploy (12:00)       
   (no note)                                              
                                                          
   "Bug report"  reviewer in @architect (11:30)         
   Note: Race condition in token validation               
                                                          

 Enter: go to message  e: edit note  d: delete  x: export  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Bookmarking:
  - Press `b` on any selected message in any view to bookmark it
  - Quick bookmark: no prompt, just saves with no note
  - `B` (shift+b): bookmark with note  opens a small input for the annotation
  - Bookmarked messages shown with a  indicator in all views
  - Bookmark stored in tui-state.json: {messageID, topic, note, createdAt}
  - Toggle: pressing `b` on an already-bookmarked message removes the bookmark (with confirmation)
- Bookmarks panel (dedicated view):
  - Access via `Ctrl+B` or from the dashboard
  - List all bookmarks sorted by creation date (newest first)
  - Each entry shows: note (if any), sender, topic, timestamp
  - Preview of the message body below the note
  - Filter bar: fuzzy search across notes and message bodies
  - Sort options: by date bookmarked, by message date, by topic, by agent
- Annotations:
  - Annotations are notes attached to specific messages (different from bookmark notes)
  - Press `a` on a selected message to add/edit an annotation
  - Annotations shown as a colored note below the message in Thread View:
    ```
     architect (15:34)
     Single-use refresh tokens...
      Your note: This was the key design decision for the auth system
    ```
  - Annotations are local-only (stored in tui-state.json)
  - Annotation shown in all views where the message appears
- Export:
  - From the bookmarks panel, press `x` to export all bookmarks as markdown
  - Export format:
    ```markdown
    # Bookmarks - Exported 2026-02-09 16:00:00
    
    ## JWT auth decision
    **From:** architect  task | **Time:** 15:34:10
    **Note:** Final decision was single-use refresh tokens
    
    > Single-use. Each refresh mints a new refresh token alongside the access token.
    > The old refresh token is immediately invalidated.
    
    ---
    ```
  - Export a single thread: `X` (shift+x) from Thread View exports the full thread as markdown
  - Output to .fmail/exports/ directory
- Bookmarks in search:
  - `has:bookmark` filter in search to find only bookmarked messages
  - `has:annotation` filter to find annotated messages

## Technical Notes
- Bookmark limit: 500 (prune oldest on save if exceeded, warn user)
- Annotations stored as map[messageID]string in tui-state.json
- Bookmark lookup: keep a set of bookmarked message IDs for O(1) lookup during render
- Export uses the same message rendering as Thread View but in markdown format
- Export directory created automatically if it doesn't exist (.fmail/exports/)

title: fmail TUI: Notifications panel and rules engine
body:
Build a notification system with configurable rules for alerting on important messages.

## Layout  Notifications Panel
```
 Notifications  3 unread 
                                                          
   15:34 HIGH  architect  @coder-1                    
    Single-use refresh tokens...                          
                                                          
   15:32 RULE "auth-watch"  architect  task           
    implement JWT auth...                                 
                                                          
   15:20 RULE "build-alerts"  tester  build           
    test suite failed: 3 failures in auth/...             
                                                          
   14:55 HIGH  deployer  deploy                       
    production deployment starting...                     
                                                          

  RULES (4 active)                                        
   "high-priority"  priority:high  bell + highlight   
   "auth-watch"  tag:auth  highlight                  
   "build-alerts"  topic:build from:tester  bell      
   "deploy-dm"  to:@deployer  bell (disabled)         
                                                          

 Enter: go to msg  n: new rule  e: edit rule  d: delete  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Notification panel:
  - Accessible via `Ctrl+N` or notification badge on the dashboard
  - Lists messages that matched notification rules, sorted by recency
  - Unread notifications marked with  (read with )
  - Each shows: time, rule that matched (or "HIGH" for priority-based), sender  target, preview
  - Enter on a notification  jump to that message in Thread View
  - `c` to clear all notifications, `x` to dismiss one
  - Badge on dashboard: shows unread notification count (e.g., "[3]" next to the Notifications keybinding)
- Notification rules:
  - Each rule has:
    - Name: user-defined label
    - Conditions (all must match):
      - topic: glob pattern for topic name
      - from: glob pattern for sender agent
      - to: glob pattern for target
      - priority: minimum priority (high, normal, low)
      - tags: required tags (any of the listed tags must be present)
      - text: regex pattern to match in message body
    - Actions:
      - highlight: bold the message in all views
      - bell: terminal bell (BEL character)
      - flash: briefly invert header bar colors
      - badge: increment notification badge on dashboard
    - Enabled: boolean toggle
  - Default rules (created on first run):
    - "high-priority": matches priority:high, actions: bell + highlight + badge
    - "direct-messages": matches messages sent to the TUI's own agent, actions: badge + highlight
- Rule editor:
  - Press `n` for new rule, `e` to edit selected rule
  - Form with fields for each condition and action
  - Toggle conditions on/off (not all are required)
  - Test button: "Run this rule against the last 100 messages" to preview matches
- Notification processing:
  - On each new message (from Subscribe()), evaluate all enabled rules
  - If any rule matches, trigger its actions
  - Store matched notifications in memory (last 200) and in tui-state.json (last 50)
- Global notification indicator:
  - In ALL views, the footer bar shows notification count if >0
  - Format: " 3" or "[N:3]" in the status bar
  - Clicking/pressing the notification keybinding opens the panel

## Technical Notes
- Rule evaluation: for each message, iterate rules and check conditions
  - Short-circuit: if any condition fails, skip to next rule
  - Glob matching: use filepath.Match for topic/from/to patterns
  - Text matching: compile regex once on rule create, apply on each message
- Performance: rule evaluation must be <1ms per message (evaluate synchronously in Subscribe handler)
- Terminal bell: write '\a' to stdout (tea.Println or raw write)
- Flash effect: set a timer that inverts header style for 500ms, then reverts
- Store notification rules in tui-state.json NotifyRules field
- Notification deduplication: don't re-notify for messages already in the notification list

title: fmail TUI: Vim-style keybindings and contextual help
body:
Implement comprehensive vim-style keybindings with a contextual help overlay.

## Deliverables
- Global keybindings (active in all views):
  - `q` / `Ctrl+C`: quit (with confirmation if compose draft exists)
  - `Esc`: back (pop view stack) / close overlay / cancel current action
  - `?`: toggle contextual help overlay
  - `1-9`: quick-switch to view by number (1=Dashboard, 2=Topics, 3=Agents, etc.)
  - `/`: open search
  - `Ctrl+N`: notifications panel
  - `Ctrl+B`: bookmarks panel
  - `:`: quick-send command bar
  - `Tab` / `Shift+Tab`: cycle between panes in split views
  - `Ctrl+L`: force redraw (clear and re-render)
  - `Ctrl+R`: force refresh data from store
- Navigation keybindings (active in list/scrollable views):
  - `j` / ``: move down
  - `k` / ``: move up
  - `h` / ``: move left / collapse / back
  - `l` / ``: move right / expand / enter
  - `g` then `g`: go to top (vim gg)
  - `G`: go to bottom
  - `Ctrl+D`: half-page down
  - `Ctrl+U`: half-page up
  - `Ctrl+F` / `PgDn`: full page down
  - `Ctrl+B` / `PgUp`: full page up (note: conflicts with bookmarks  use Ctrl+B only when not in a scrollable context)
  - `n` / `N`: next/previous search result
  - `Enter`: select / open / expand
  - `Space`: toggle selection / pause-resume in Live Tail
- View-specific keybindings:
  - Thread View: `r` reply, `R` DM reply, `b` bookmark, `B` bookmark+note, `a` annotate, `f` flat/threaded toggle
  - Topic Browser: `s` sort, `*` star, `d` toggle DMs, `n` new message
  - Agent Roster: `s` sort, `[`/`]` adjust time range
  - Timeline: `+`/`-` zoom, `s` swim-lane toggle, `n` jump to now, `t` jump to time
  - Live Tail: `Space` pause/resume, `f` filter, `h` highlight, `c` clear filter
  - Stats: `[`/`]` adjust time range, `r` refresh
  - Replay: `Space` play/pause, `1-4` speed, ``/`` skip, `m` mark, `'` jump to mark
- Contextual help overlay:
  - Press `?` to toggle
  - Semi-transparent overlay showing keybindings for the CURRENT view
  - Organized by category: Navigation, Actions, View-specific
  - Shows key + description in two columns
  - Dismiss with `?` again, `Esc`, or any action key
  - At the bottom: "Global: q quit | / search | ? help | 1-9 views"
- Key conflict resolution:
  - View-specific bindings take priority over global when in that view
  - Navigation bindings take priority over global in scrollable views
  - Document all conflicts and their resolution in code comments
- Keybinding configuration (future, but design for it now):
  - All keybindings defined in a central keymap struct
  - Easy to override from a config file in the future

## Technical Notes
- Bubbletea key handling: match on tea.KeyMsg in Update()
- For multi-key sequences (gg): implement a pending-key state
  - On `g`: set pendingKey='g', start a 500ms timer
  - On second `g` within timeout: execute gg action
  - On timeout or different key: cancel pending
- For key categories, create a KeyMap struct:
  ```go
  type KeyMap struct {
      Quit      key.Binding
      Back      key.Binding
      Help      key.Binding
      Search    key.Binding
      // ... etc
  }
  ```
- Use charmbracelet/bubbles/key for binding definitions
- Help overlay: render as a lipgloss-styled box centered on screen with 50% opacity effect (dim background)
- Test all keybindings on macOS Terminal, iTerm2, and common Linux terminals

title: fmail TUI: Layout modes (single, split, dashboard, zen)
body:
Implement configurable layout modes for different workflows and screen sizes.

## Layout Modes

### Single Pane (default for narrow terminals)
```

         Active View          
         (full width)         
                              
                              

```
- One view fills the entire terminal
- Navigate between views with number keys or breadcrumbs
- Best for terminals <100 cols

### Split Pane (default for wide terminals)
```

  Left Pane     Right Pane   
  (list/nav)    (detail)     
                             
                             

```
- Left: navigation (topic list, agent list, search results)
- Right: detail (thread view, message preview, agent detail)
- Tab to switch focus between panes
- Drag divider with mouse (or `|` key to adjust split ratio)
- Split ratio: 30/70 default, adjustable in 10% increments
- Left pane can be collapsed with `Ctrl+\`

### Dashboard (multi-pane grid)
```

  Agents        Live Feed    
                             

  Topics        Stats/Graph  
                             

```
- 2x2 grid showing 4 views simultaneously
- Each quadrant shows a compact version of a view
- Configurable: choose which view goes in each quadrant
  - Press `Ctrl+1` through `Ctrl+4` to change quadrant content
  - Dropdown menu with available views
- Focus one quadrant with Tab, Enter to expand to full screen
- Grid sizes: 2x1 (two rows), 1x2 (two cols), 2x2, 1x3, 3x1
- Configure with `Ctrl+G` (grid layout selector)

### Zen Mode
```

                              
    (just the message stream  
     no chrome, no borders,   
     no status bar)           
                              

```
- Minimal: only the message content, no UI chrome
- No header, no footer, no borders
- Just the live feed or current thread
- Keybindings still work, `?` still shows help
- Toggle with `Ctrl+Z` or `z` then `z` (like vim zen mode)

## Deliverables
- Layout manager:
  - `internal/fmailtui/layout/layout.go`
  - LayoutMode enum: Single, Split, Dashboard, Zen
  - LayoutManager struct: manages pane arrangement, sizes, and focus
  - Pane struct: {ViewID, X, Y, Width, Height, Focused bool}
  - Responsive: auto-switch from Split to Single when terminal width <100
  - Auto-switch from Dashboard to Split when terminal width <140
- Split pane controls:
  - Tab: cycle focus
  - `|` or `Ctrl+W` then `+`/`-`: adjust split ratio
  - `Ctrl+W` then `h`/`l`: move focus left/right
  - `Ctrl+W` then `j`/`k`: move focus up/down (in dashboard mode)
  - `Ctrl+W` then `o`: expand focused pane to full screen (toggle)
- Layout persistence:
  - Save current layout mode and pane arrangement in tui-state.json
  - Restore on next launch
  - Default layout preference configurable in Preferences
- View rendering:
  - Each view implements a `Render(width, height int) string` method
  - Views adapt their rendering to the available space:
    - Compact mode: abbreviated columns, shorter previews, no decorative borders
    - Full mode: all columns, full previews, styled borders
  - Each view reports a minimum size (e.g., Thread View needs at least 40 cols)
  - If pane smaller than minimum, show a "pane too small" placeholder

## Technical Notes
- Layout computation: given terminal (W, H), compute pane rectangles
- Split ratio stored as float64 (0.0-1.0), default 0.35 for left pane
- Dashboard grid: divide available space equally, with 1-char borders between panes
- Zen mode: simply render the active view at full terminal size with no chrome
- Responsive breakpoints: configurable but defaults at 80/100/140 columns
- Mouse support (optional, Bubbletea supports it): click to focus pane, drag divider
- Rendering order: render each pane independently, then compose with lipgloss.JoinHorizontal/Vertical

title: fmail TUI: Connection status bar and system indicators
body:
Build the persistent status bar showing connection state, throughput, and system indicators.

## Layout
```

  fmail TUI  project: forge  agent: tui-viewer           <- header
                                                          
  ... (active view content) ...                           
                                                          
  forged:connected  12 msg/m  6 agents   3  15:34  <- status bar

```

## Deliverables
- Header bar:
  - Left: "fmail TUI" branding + current view name breadcrumb
  - Center: project name (from .fmail/project.json or FMAIL_PROJECT)
  - Right: agent identity (who am I in fmail) + clock (HH:MM)
  - Styled with theme accent color, bold
- Status bar (bottom):
  - Connection indicator:
    - ` connected` (green)  connected to forged via socket, real-time delivery active
    - ` polling` (yellow)  standalone mode, polling every N ms
    - ` disconnected` (red)  was connected to forged but lost connection
    - ` reconnecting` (yellow, blinking)  attempting to reconnect to forged
    - Show the connection method: "unix:.fmail/forged.sock" or "tcp:127.0.0.1:7463" or "file:100ms"
  - Message throughput:
    - Rolling messages-per-minute counter
    - Format: "12 msg/m" or "0 msg/m"
    - Sparkline of last 10 minutes if space allows: "12 msg/m "
  - Agent count:
    - "6 agents"  count of agents seen in the last 10 minutes
    - Click/keybinding to jump to Agent Roster
  - Notification badge:
    - " 3" or "[N:3]"  unread notification count
    - Highlighted/bold when count >0
    - Hidden when count =0
  - Clock:
    - Current time HH:MM, updates every minute
    - Useful for correlating with message timestamps
  - Disk usage (optional, shown if space):
    - ".fmail: 2.3MB"  total size of the .fmail directory
    - Warning indicator if >100MB
- Reconnection behavior:
  - If forged connection drops, immediately switch to file-based polling
  - Attempt reconnection every 5 seconds (with exponential backoff up to 60s)
  - On successful reconnect, switch back to socket mode
  - Show reconnection attempt count: " reconnecting (attempt 3/10)"
  - After max attempts, stay in polling mode and show " disconnected (using file polling)"
- Breadcrumb trail:
  - In the header, show the navigation path: "Dashboard > Topics > task"
  - Clickable breadcrumbs (or navigable with Ctrl+ to go up a level)
  - Based on the view stack
- Pane-aware status:
  - In split/dashboard mode, status bar spans the full width
  - Active pane indicator in the status bar
  - Header shows the focused pane's breadcrumb

## Technical Notes
- Status bar rendered as a single lipgloss.Render() call with JoinHorizontal for segments
- Each segment has a min-width; hide optional segments (disk usage, sparkline) if terminal too narrow
- Priority order for space allocation: connection > throughput > agents > notifications > clock > disk
- Message throughput: ring buffer of 600 timestamps (10 minutes at 1/sec resolution)
  - Count entries in last 60s for msg/min
- Connection monitoring: goroutine that pings forged every 5s, updates connection state
  - Use tea.Cmd to send connection state changes to the Bubbletea model
- Clock: tea.Tick every 60 seconds to update the time display
- Sparkline in status bar: 10 characters, each representing 1 minute of the last 10 minutes
  - Height proportional to message count in that minute

title: fmail TUI: Theme support and message rendering polish
body:
Polish the visual rendering of messages and ensure full theme support across all views.

## Deliverables

### Message Rendering Excellence
- Message card rendering:
  - Styled box with agent-colored left border (2px/chars)
  - Header: "agent-name" (bold, in agent color) + " 2m ago" (muted)  or full timestamp on focus
  - Priority badge inline: [HIGH] in red, [LOW] in dim  only shown for non-normal priority
  - Tag pills: [auth] [urgent]  each in a subtle rounded-corner style (if terminal supports)
  - Reply indicator: " replying to agent-name" in muted text above the body
  - Body: word-wrapped to available width, with proper Unicode handling
  - Code blocks (``` fenced): rendered with a distinct background color and monospace indicator
  - Inline code (`backtick`): subtle background highlight
  - URLs: underlined (if terminal supports)
  - Long messages (>10 lines): truncated with "[+15 more lines]"  expandable with Enter
  - Unread messages: bold left border + accent dot
  - Bookmarked messages:  indicator in the header
  - Annotated messages:  note shown below the body in a different-colored box

### Theme System
- Two complete themes:
  - Default: dark background assumed, vibrant colors, subtle borders
  - High contrast: bright colors on pure black, thick borders, increased spacing
- Theme switching: `Ctrl+T` cycles themes, or set in preferences
- Each theme defines:
  - Primary, secondary, accent, muted, error, warning, success colors
  - Background and foreground defaults
  - Border style (rounded, sharp, double, hidden)
  - Agent color palette (12-16 colors, different per theme for contrast)
  - Priority color mapping
  - Status color mapping
- All views must respect the active theme  no hardcoded colors anywhere
- Theme-aware rendering helpers:
  ```go
  func (t Theme) MessageCard(msg fmail.Message, selected bool, compact bool) string
  func (t Theme) AgentBadge(name string, status AgentStatus) string
  func (t Theme) TopicPill(name string, heat HeatLevel) string
  func (t Theme) PriorityBadge(priority string) string
  func (t Theme) TagPill(tag string) string
  func (t Theme) Timestamp(t time.Time, relative bool) string
  func (t Theme) Sparkline(values []float64, width int) string
  ```

### Rendering Optimizations
- Memoize rendered message cards: cache the rendered string keyed by (messageID, width, selected, theme)
- Invalidate cache on: theme change, terminal resize, selection change
- Viewport virtualization: only render messages visible in the scroll window + 10 buffer
- Batch re-renders: coalesce multiple state changes into a single re-render (max 1 per 50ms)
- Diff rendering: where possible, only re-render changed portions

### Special Character Support
- Box-drawing characters:  for borders and tree connectors
- Block characters:  for heatmaps and activity bars
- Braille:  for high-resolution sparklines
- Unicode arrows:       for navigation and flow indicators
- Graceful fallback: detect terminal capability, fall back to ASCII (+-|) if Unicode unsupported

## Technical Notes
- Use lipgloss.NewStyle().Foreground/Background/Bold/Italic for all styling
- Agent colors: precomputed and cached in a global AgentColorCache
- Word wrapping: use lipgloss.Width() for proper Unicode width calculation
  - CJK characters, emoji, etc. may be double-width
- Code block detection: scan for ``` in message body, render content between with CodeBlockStyle
- Truncation: count rendered lines (not bytes/chars), truncate at line boundary
- Theme hot-reload: changing theme should re-render all cached content (flush render cache)

title: fmail TUI: Compose overlay and quick-send bar
body:
Build the foundational compose UI components: the modal overlay for composing messages and the quick-send command bar. This is the plumbing that the full Human Operator Console (forge-p2m) builds on.

## Layout  Compose Overlay
```
 Compose 
                                                          
  To: task_______        (Tab to autocomplete)            
  Priority: [normal ]                                    
  Tags: auth, urgent_    (comma-separated)                
  Reply to: 20260209-153000-0001  (auto-filled)          
                                                          
   
   Here's the implementation plan for JWT auth:         
                                                        
   1. RS256 signing with rotating keys                  
   2. 15-minute access token expiry                     
   3. Single-use refresh tokens                         
                                                        
   I'll start with the token service.                   
   
                                                          
  [Ctrl+Enter: Send]  [Esc: Cancel]  [Tab: Next field]   

```

## Deliverables
- Compose overlay (modal):
  - Triggered by: `n` (new message), `r` (reply to selected message)
  - Semi-transparent overlay on top of current view
  - Fields:
    - To: text input with tab-completion for agent names (@agent) and topic names
      - Autocomplete dropdown showing matching agents/topics as user types
      - Pre-filled when replying (to = sender of selected message) or when in a topic view
    - Priority: dropdown selector (low / normal / high), default normal
    - Tags: comma-separated text input with tab-completion for existing tags
    - Reply to: auto-filled when using `r`, shows the parent message ID + preview
    - Body: multi-line text area (main input)
  - Tab cycles between fields, Enter in single-line fields moves to next field
  - Ctrl+Enter: send the message
  - Esc: cancel (with confirmation if body is non-empty: "Discard draft?")
- Message sending:
  - Sends via the data provider (which uses forged socket if available, file store otherwise)
  - Show sending indicator ("Sending...") with spinner
  - On success: close overlay, show brief "Sent " notification, message appears in feed
  - On error: show error message in the overlay, keep draft intact for retry
  - Set FMAIL_AGENT identity from CLI flag or auto-detect
- Reply mode:
  - `r` on a selected message  opens compose with:
    - To: pre-filled with the topic (or @sender for DMs)
    - Reply to: set to the selected message's ID
    - Body: empty, but header shows "Replying to: <first line of parent message>"
  - `R` (shift+r)  reply to sender directly (DM) regardless of where the original was posted
- Quick send bar:
  - From any view, press `:` to open a one-line quick send bar at the bottom of the screen
  - Syntax: `:<target> <message>` (e.g., `:task implement JWT auth`)
  - Press Enter to send immediately
  - Tab completion for target names in the quick send bar
  - No priority/tag/reply-to options (uses defaults)
  - Great for fast, informal messages
  - History: / to cycle through previous quick-sends
- Draft persistence:
  - If user navigates away from compose (Esc), offer to save draft
  - Drafts stored in tui-state.json
  - On next compose, offer to restore last draft if target matches

## Technical Notes
- Multi-line text input: use charmbracelet/bubbles textarea component
- Tab completion: build a trie or sorted list of known agents/topics, filter on prefix
- Autocomplete dropdown: rendered as a small list below the input, navigate with /
- Send via fmail store: write JSON message file to .fmail/topics/<topic>/ or .fmail/dm/<agent>/
  - Or send via forged socket: {"cmd":"send","to":"<target>","body":"<msg>","agent":"<self>"}
- Identity: the TUI needs to know "who am I"  set via --agent flag or FMAIL_AGENT env var
  - If not set, register as "tui-<pid>" or prompt user on first send
- Ctrl+Enter detection: tea.KeyMsg with ctrl+enter (may need platform-specific handling)

title: fmail TUI: Human Operator Console  command center for directing agents
body:
Build a dedicated "Operator Console" view designed specifically for a human user sitting at the TUI, directing and interacting with a swarm of agents. This goes far beyond basic compose  it's the command center for a human orchestrating AI agents.

## Layout  Operator Console
```
 Operator Console  you: tormod 
                                                          
  CONVERSATION with architect  
    architect (15:30)                                  
   Here's my analysis of the auth module. I found 3     
   issues: 1) Token expiry not enforced 2) Missing      
   refresh rotation 3) No rate limiting on login.       
                                                        
    you (15:32)                                        
   Good catches. Fix #1 and #2 now, create a ticket     
   for #3. Use single-use refresh tokens.               
                                                        
    architect (15:33)                                  
   On it. I'll also loop in coder-1 for the refresh     
   token implementation.                                
                                                        
  
   QUICK ACTIONS                                        
   [1] Broadcast to all  [2] @architect  [3] @coder-1  
   [4]  task topic      [5]  build topic              
  
                                                        
   > Fix the token rotation and let me know when the_   
                                                        
   To: @architect  Priority: normal  Ctrl+Enter: Send 
  
                                                          
  AGENT STATUS  
   architect  "fixing token expiry"         30s ago    
   coder-1    "implementing refresh flow"   1m ago     
   tester     "waiting for build"           5m ago     

 1-5: quick target  Tab: switch conversation  Esc: back
```

## Deliverables

### Chat-Style Conversation View
- Shows YOUR conversation history with the currently selected agent/topic
- Messages displayed in a familiar chat-bubble style:
  - Your messages: right-aligned or distinct "you" color/style, clearly distinguished
  - Agent messages: left-aligned with agent color
  - Timestamps between message groups (not on every message)
  - "Typing..." or "working..." indicator based on agent status updates
- Conversation list sidebar (left, collapsible):
  - All agents and topics you've interacted with, sorted by recency
  - Unread badges per conversation
  - Tab or number keys to switch between conversations
  - New conversation: `n` to start composing to a new target
- Auto-follow: conversation auto-scrolls when new messages arrive from the focused agent
- Context display: when an agent references a topic message in a DM, show an inline preview of that message

### Compose Area (Always Visible)
- Persistent compose area at the bottom of the console  NOT a modal overlay
- Always visible, always ready for input (like a real chat app)
- Multi-line text area with word wrap
- Current target shown in the compose footer: "To: @architect" with easy switching
- Target switching:
  - Number keys (1-9) for quick-access targets (most recent conversations)
  - Tab-completion in a "To:" prefix if you want to change target inline
  - `/dm architect` to switch to a specific agent
  - `/topic task` to switch to a specific topic
- Slash commands in the compose area:
  - `/broadcast <msg>`  send to all active agents
  - `/dm <agent> <msg>`  quick DM without switching context
  - `/topic <name> <msg>`  post to a topic without switching
  - `/status`  show all agents and their current status
  - `/assign <agent> <task>`  send a task assignment (high priority, tagged "assignment")
  - `/ask <agent> <question>`  send a question (tagged "question", expects reply)
  - `/approve <msg-id>`  reply with approval (tagged "approved")
  - `/reject <msg-id> <reason>`  reply with rejection (tagged "rejected")
  - `/priority high|normal|low`  set priority for next message
  - `/tag <tags...>`  set tags for next message
- Command palette: `Ctrl+P` shows all available slash commands with descriptions
- Send with Enter (single line) or Ctrl+Enter (multi-line mode toggle with Ctrl+M)

### Quick Actions Bar
- Horizontal bar above the compose area with numbered quick-access targets
- Shows the 5-9 most relevant targets:
  - Agents who recently messaged you (highest priority)
  - Topics with recent activity
  - Agents you recently messaged
- Number keys 1-9 to instantly switch compose target
- Visual indicator showing which target is currently active
- Customizable: pin favorite targets to specific number slots (persisted)

### Agent Status Ticker
- Compact agent status bar below or beside the conversation
- Shows all known agents with: presence dot, name, status message, last activity
- Live-updating as agents send status updates
- Click/select an agent to start a conversation with them
- Visual grouping: "active" agents (online) at top, "idle" at bottom

### Broadcast & Multi-Send
- Broadcast mode: send a message to ALL active agents simultaneously
  - Trigger with `/broadcast` or a dedicated keybinding (Ctrl+A for "all")
  - Confirmation prompt: "Send to 6 agents? [y/N]"
  - Each agent gets an individual DM (not a topic post)
  - Or post to a configurable "announcements" topic
- Multi-select: hold Ctrl and click/select multiple agents, compose one message sent to all
- Group compose: create ad-hoc groups (e.g., "frontend team" = coder-1, coder-2, designer)
  - `/group create frontend coder-1 coder-2 designer`
  - `/group frontend <msg>` to message the whole group

### Feedback & Approval Workflow
- When an agent sends a message tagged "question" or "needs-approval":
  - Message highlighted with a distinct border/badge
  - Inline action buttons: [Approve] [Reject] [Reply]
  - `y` to approve (sends reply tagged "approved")
  - `x` to reject (opens compose for rejection reason)
  - These appear in the notification panel AND in the conversation
- Feedback templates:
  - Quick reactions: `:thumbsup:`, `:thumbsdown:`, `:eyes:`  sent as short reply messages
  - Template library: pre-written responses for common patterns
    - "Looks good, proceed" / "Hold off, let me review" / "Needs changes: ..."
  - Configurable templates in tui-state.json
- Priority escalation: when you send a high-priority message, it gets a visual "urgent" treatment in the agent's view

### Notification Integration
- Unread message count per conversation shown in sidebar
- Desktop notification (terminal bell) when an agent DMs you
- Flash/highlight when an agent mentions your name in a topic
- "Waiting for reply" indicators: if you asked a question >5m ago with no response, show a subtle reminder

### Identity & Presence
- Your identity prominently shown: "you: tormod" in the header
- Set via `--agent` flag, `FMAIL_AGENT` env, or prompted on first launch
- Your status: set with `/mystatus working on auth review`  visible to all agents
- Auto-presence: TUI automatically registers you as an active agent while open
  - Updates last_seen on every interaction
  - Clears presence on exit (or marks as "offline")

## Technical Notes
- The operator console is a new view (not a replacement for the compose overlay)
- It can be the DEFAULT view when launched with `fmail tui --operator` or `-o` flag
- Conversation history: aggregated from DMs sent/received + topic messages where the user participated
- For "chat style" rendering: track which messages are "mine" vs "theirs" based on FMAIL_AGENT identity
- Quick action targets: computed from recent message history, refreshed on new messages
- Slash command parser: split on first space, match command prefix, pass rest as args
- Group storage: tui-state.json under a "groups" key: map[string][]string

title: Epic: fmail TUI v2 perf + UX stabilization
body:
Goal: first pass stabilization of fmail TUI UX + performance.

User issue:
- TUI feels rough visually.
- Loading full message state feels too slow.

Scope:
- Data-provider hot paths (topics/dm/search/subscribe).
- View reload strategy (timeline/topics/dashboard/stats/graph).
- Faster initial load and interaction responsiveness.
- Guardrails: measurable budgets, regression tests, perf harness.

Success:
- Cold start and core view navigation feel immediate on medium stores.
- No repeated full-store scans on short timer ticks.
- Team has benchmark + smoke commands to catch regressions.

title: tmp-shape-check-delete-later
body: shape check

title: fmail TUI perf: incremental topic/DM metadata index
body:
Scope:
- Rework FileProvider metadata path to avoid full message loads on each Topics/DMConversations call.
- Add incremental metadata cache/index keyed by topic + dm peer (message count, last activity, participants, last id).
- Invalidate incrementally from Subscribe/new-file detection rather than broad rescans.
- Add config surface for cache TTL defaults tuned for file store.

Acceptance:
- Topics()/DMConversations() avoid loading all message bodies on steady-state calls.
- Repeated metadata calls are near-constant time after warmup.

Tests:
- Unit tests for cache correctness and invalidation.
- Regression test for repeated Topics()/DMConversations() call count/behavior.

title: fmail TUI perf: subscribe polling + scan dedupe
body:
Scope:
- Optimize FileProvider Subscribe() polling:
  - avoid repeated full directory walks per tick.
  - coalesce bursts and dedupe repeated scans.
  - support adaptive/backoff polling intervals.
- Tune defaults from current aggressive values to balanced latency/cpu.
- Expose poll/cache knobs in fmail TUI config.

Acceptance:
- Lower idle CPU during TUI run with no new messages.
- New message detection remains timely.

Tests:
- Unit tests for watcher backoff/coalescing behavior.
- Integration-style test for delivery order + no duplicates.

title: fmail TUI perf: topics/dashboard incremental refresh
body:
Scope:
- Refactor topics/dashboard refresh so message-event tick does not trigger broad reload every cycle.
- Replace full Messages()/DMs() reload loops with incremental counters/state updates.
- Unread and hot-topic counts computed from cached metadata + read markers.

Acceptance:
- topics/dashboard view update cost scales with delta, not total store size.
- No repeated full-topic scan on every timer tick.

Tests:
- Regression tests for unread/hot counts correctness.
- Tests for reload throttling/debouncing behavior.

title: fmail TUI perf: timeline windowing + lazy paging
body:
Scope:
- Redesign timeline data flow for bounded window reads.
- Add lazy paging/chunking (initial window + fetch more on demand).
- Prevent full all-topics/all-dm aggregation on each refresh.

Acceptance:
- Timeline initial load bounded and fast.
- Scroll/navigation does not stall when history grows.

Tests:
- Unit tests for window bounds/paging logic.
- Integration test for incremental timeline growth.

title: fmail TUI perf: incremental search index + TTL tuning

title: Epic: Rust Rewrite (non-legacy parity, final switch)
body:
Goal:
- Rewrite Forge to Rust in-repo.
- Preserve parity for all non-legacy behavior.
- Execute single final switch, with continuous parity checks before cutover.

In scope:
- Loops runtime + smart-stop + queue semantics.
- Profiles/pools/config/runtime ownership behavior.
- forge CLI non-legacy commands.
- forged daemon + forge-agent-runner protocols.
- fmail core/CLI/TUI.
- Loop TUI + fmail TUI on FrankenTUI.

Out of scope:
- Legacy interactive command setup and disabled legacy paths.

Definition of done:
- Rust binaries pass parity matrix + CI gates.
- Full unit test coverage policy enforced for Rust crates.
- Single final switch completed with rollback plan validated.
